title: Justice Department loses battle to keep unredacted Mueller report from Congress
text:
Grand-jury evidence collected by the former special counsel investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election must be transmitted to Congress, a federal judge ruled on Friday, rejecting a Trump administration bid to keep the material secret.

U.S. District Judge Beryl A. Howell granted a request from the Democrat-led House Judiciary Committee for access to material that was redacted from Robert Mueller’s report earlier this year, as well as exhibits and transcripts referenced in the report.

Typically, grand-jury material is secret, and the Justice Department had fought a legal battle to avoid disclosure to Congress. But Democrats have said they need the underlying material, which touches on not only Russian interference but President Trump’s efforts to impede the probe, to determine whether Trump committed an impeachable offense.

Friday order gives the Justice Department till next Wednesday to comply. An appeal remains possible.

The committee “has shown that it needs the grand jury material referenced and cited in the Mueller Report to avoid a possible injustice in the impeachment inquiry, that this need for disclosure is greater than the need for continued secrecy,” Judge Howell ruled. The Obama appointee heard the case in her capacity as chief justice for the federal district court in Washington, D.C. As chief judge, she authorized and supervised the grand jury used by Mueller.

An expanded version of this report appears at WSJ.com.
